reasoning:
The critique targets one supporting pillar of the paper’s case that (on unbounded-linear views) a mostly-great future is a narrow target: the claim that value-per-resource is fat-tailed such that the best uses of matter/energy are vastly better than typical uses. If this were successfully undermined, it would weaken (but not collapse) the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion, because the paper has several other independent routes to fussiness (multiplicative ‘many dimensions’ fragility; bounded-view arguments; bads-vs-goods aggregation). Hence moderate centrality.

The argument has some bite—physical efficiency is indeed bounded by thermodynamics (e.g., Landauer) and other physical limits, so “unbounded exponential improvement forever” is not available. However, the paper’s fat-tail claim is not clearly committed to unbounded physical efficiency; fat-tailed (or highly skewed) value density can arise even under hard physical ceilings, and a truncated tail can still permit astronomically large ratios across feasible configurations. The critique also doesn’t engage the paper’s key step that the space of configurations is huge and that most are far from optimal on the author’s moral metric; physical bounds alone don’t show the optimum-vs-typical gap is small. So it only modestly weakens the attacked sub-claim.

Correctness is mixed: the physics-bounds premise is largely right, but the conclusion that truncation makes eutopia a “broad plateau” rather than a “sharp peak” is under-argued and not generally implied. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Physical limits truncate the fat tail, making optimal resource use a plateau
